title: Lesson 12: Mitosis – Nuclear Division
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding the four stages of mitosis (PMAT): prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. Focus on chromosome behaviour and spindle fibre function.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the four stages of mitosis (prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase) in correct sequence.
Students can identify the key events occurring at each stage (chromosome condensation, spindle formation, alignment, separation).
Students can explain the significance of sister chromatid separation in maintaining chromosome number.

prerequisites.description: Cell cycle, S phase—DNA already replicated

engagementHook.title: The Molecular Dance
engagementHook.content: Show time-lapse video of cell dividing. 'Watch carefully—those X-shaped structures are your chromosomes, and they're performing the most precise dance in biology. One mistake, and the daughter cells get the wrong genetic instructions. Today we break down this dance into four steps: Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, Telophase (PMAT).'

keyConcepts.definition: Division of the nucleus into two genetically identical daughter nuclei. Maintains chromosome number (2n → 2n).
Chromatin condenses into visible chromosomes (each with two sister chromatids joined at centromere); nuclear envelope breaks down; spindle forms (microtubules from centrioles in animal cells).
Chromosomes align at the cell equator (metaphase plate); spindle fibres attach to centromeres (kinetochores).
Sister chromatids separate and are pulled to opposite poles by spindle fibres (now called daughter chromosomes).
Chromosomes arrive at poles, decondense (uncoil), nuclear envelopes reform; spindle disassembles.
Remains constant (diploid to diploid) because sister chromatids separate (each new cell gets complete set).

misconceptions.correction: Mitosis is nuclear division only. Cytokinesis (Lesson 13) is cell/cytoplasm division.
Chromosomes exist as chromatin all the time but are only visible as distinct structures during prophase-metaphase.

misconceptions.misconception: The cell splits in half during anaphase
misconceptions.correction: Anaphase separates chromosomes; cell division (cytokinesis) happens later.

contentSections.title: Chromosome Structure During Mitosis
contentSections.content: Show duplicated chromosome (X-shape) with two sister chromatids joined at centromere. Label: chromatid, centromere, kinetochore (where spindle attaches). Show condensation from chromatin thread to chromosome.
keyPoints: Each chromosome replicated in S phase consists of two sister chromatids
contentSections.example: Down syndrome can result from nondisjunction (failure to separate properly—preview error).

contentSections.title: The Four Stages of Mitosis
contentSections.content: Four panels showing: (1) Prophase—condensing chromosomes, breaking nucleus; (2) Metaphase—alignment at middle; (3) Anaphase—V-shape chromosomes moving apart; (4) Telophase—two forming nuclei.
keyPoints: Spindle microtubules attach and move chromosomes

multipleChoice.question: During which stage of mitosis do the sister chromatids separate and move to opposite poles?
multipleChoice.rationale: Anaphase definition. Sister chromatids are pulled apart toward opposite poles.

multipleChoice.question: The nuclear envelope breaks down during:
multipleChoice.rationale: Prophase events. Nuclear envelope disassembles to allow spindle access to chromosomes.

multipleChoice.question: A cell with 46 chromosomes enters mitosis. After S phase but before anaphase, each chromosome consists of:
multipleChoice.rationale: Chromosome vs chromatid counting. After S phase: 46 chromosomes, 92 chromatids.

shortAnswer.question: Describe the events occurring during metaphase of mitosis. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Chromosomes align at the cell equator (metaphase plate/middle of cell)
1 mark: Spindle fibres (microtubules) attach to the centromeres of chromosomes

shortAnswer.question: Explain why mitosis is described as producing 'genetically identical' daughter nuclei. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Sister chromatids are identical copies of each other (from DNA replication in S phase)
1 mark: When they separate in anaphase, each daughter nucleus receives an identical set/complement of chromosomes (same genetic information)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'the DNA is copied' without explaining the separation mechanism.

definitions: Prophase: Chromosomes condense; nuclear envelope breaks down; spindle forms.
Metaphase: Chromosomes line up at the equator.
Anaphase: Sister chromatids separate and move to opposite poles.
Telophase: Nuclear envelopes reform; chromosomes decondense.

shortAnswer: During metaphase, the chromosomes align at the cell equator (also called the metaphase plate), which is the middle of the cell. Spindle fibres (microtubules) attach to the centromeres of each chromosome at specialised protein structures called kinetochores. This alignment ensures that when the sister chromatids separate, each daughter cell will receive an identical set of chromosomes.

Mitosis produces genetically identical daughter nuclei because the sister chromatids are identical copies of each other, having been produced by DNA replication during the S phase of interphase. During anaphase, these sister chromatids separate and move to opposite poles of the cell. As a result, each daughter nucleus receives an identical complement of chromosomes with the same genetic information as the parent cell.
